question: Elschnigs pearls are seen in?
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., After cataract After cataract (Secondary cataract or posterior capsular opacification)o Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) is seen after ECCE. Opacification of the posterior capsule is caused by postoperative proliferation of cells in the capsular bag and is the most common complication of ECCE. o After cataract may present as thickened posterior capsule, or dense membranous after cataract or Soemmering's ring which refers to a thick ring of after cataract formed behind the iris, enclosed between the two layers of capsule or Elschnig's pearls in which the vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells are clustered like soap bubbles along the osterior capsule. o After cataract, if thin, can be cleared centrally by Nd: YAG laser capsulotomy. Discission with cystitome or zeigler's knife may also be used. Thick membranous after cataract needs surgical membranectomy.

question: Cata ract in diabetes -
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., Snowflake. Diabetic cataracto Cataract is considered as a major cause of visual impairment in diabetic patients. Senile cataract tends to develop at an earlier age and more rapidly than usual in diabetic patients, o The enzyme aldolase reductase catalyzes the reduction of glucose to sorbitol through the polyol pathway, a process linked to the development of diabetic cataract. NADPH* dependent aldolase reductase reduces excessive glucose to sorbitol and intracellular accumulation of sorbitol leads to osmotic changes resulting in hydropic lens fibers that degenerate and form sugar cataract, o The typical diabetic cataract is snowflake cataract, i. e., dense white subcapsular opacities in the anterior and posterior cortex resembling a snowstorm. o As blood- sugar levels fluctuate, visual acuity and refractive error can change - Fluctating refractive error. This causes frequent change in optimal eyeglass prescription.

question: In a patient, highest visual morbidity is seen in:
exp: Ans: C (Posterior subcapsular cataract) Ref: Basok Essentials of Ophthalmology. 5th edition, pg. 248: Parson's Diseases of the Eye 21st edition pg no 262. Explanation: Posterior subcapsular cataract or posterior cortical cataract: The opacity in the posterior cortex is close to the nodal point of the lens. Nodal point 7. 0S mm from the anterior surface of the cornea.* Posterior cortical cataract is at the visual axis so during day time pupil constricts - Day Blindness.

IS ADPH+ dependent aldolase reductase reduces excessive glucose to sorbitol and intracellular accumulation of sorbitol leads to osmotic changes resulting in hydropic lens fibers that degenerate and form sugar cataract. o The typical diabetic cataract is snowflake cataract, i. e., dense white subcapsular opacities in the anterior and posterior cortex resembling a snowstorm.

question: Chronic systemic steroid use causes?
exp: ANSWER: (D) Cataract. REF: khurana 4th ed p. 428. Chronic systemic steroid use causes cataract while chronic topical steroid use causes glaucoma. Injudicious use of topical steroid cause: Glaucoma. Activation of infection. Dry eye. Ptosis. Injudicious use of systemic steroids leads to following ocular complications: Cataract. Delayed wound healing. Infections of eye. Papilloedema. CRVO

question: Polychromatic lusture is seen in -
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., Complicated cataract Complicated cataracto Complicated cataract refers to the lens opacification secondary to some other intraocular disease. Anterior uveitis is the most common cause. Other causes are posterior uveitis, pars planitis, comeal ulcer, ciliary body tumors, degenerative myopia, retinitis pigmentosa and retinal detachment. o Typically complicated cataracts occur in two forms:-Posterior cortical complicated cataract. This type of cataract is due to affections of posterior segment. This cataract is located in a posterior subcapsular cataract and typically opacification starts in the posterior part of the cortex in the axial region (Posterior cortical cataract or posterior subcapsular cataract). On slit lamp examination the opacities have "bread- crumb" appearance. A characteristic sign is presence of polychromatic lusture of red, green and blues. Anterior cortical complicated cataract This is due to the affection of anterior segment like glaucoma or anterior uveitis.

question: Anterior polar cataract develope in: (PGI June 2009)
exp: Ans: B (Penetrating corneal injury) Anterior Polar Cataract. QIt involves the central part ofthe anterior capsule & the adjoining superficial- most cortex. May arise in -Due to corneal perforation. Cataract may follow contact of the lens capsule with the back of cornea. usually after perforation due to ophthalmia neonatorum or any other cause. Due to delayed development of anterior chamber: In this case the opacity is congenital, usually b/lr stationary & visually insignificant. Anterior Polar CataractQ (Lens & Cataract - American Academy of Ophthalmology 2007-2008/34])# Anterior polar cataract are usually small, bilateral, symmetric, non progressive opacities that do not impair vision. They are frequently inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern# Sometimes seen in association with other ocular abnormalities, including microphthalmos, persistent papillary membrane & anterior lenticonus5'Extra Edge. Type of cataract. Cause. Snowflake/ Snow storm cataract. QDiabetes mellitus. QSunflower /Petals of flower cataracts. Wilson diseaseQ Chalcosis. QPenetrating trauma. Vossius ring on anterior surface of lens. Rossette shaped cataract. QBlunt trauma. QChristmas tree cataract. QMyotonic dystrophica. QOil drop cataract. QDust like lenticular opacity. Galactosemia. QPosterior cortical Bread's crumb appearance. Polychromatic lusture /Rainbow cataract. Complicated cataract. QMorgagnian cataract. QHypermature senile cataract

question: Glass blowers cataract is caused due to -
exp: Ans. is 'c' i. e. Infrared radiation o Glassblower's cataracts is formed by many years or decades of exposure to infrared radiaiton while working in the occupation of glass blowing, or working close to hot or molten metals such with metal foundry workers or blacksmiths. o Glassblower's cataracts are due to chronic exposure to infrared radiation emitted due to heating of glass or molten metal. The infrared radiation is absorbed by the iris and lens of the eye. This causes cataracts after decades of exposure. This condition may be pre vented by wearing protective glasses while practicing these occupations.

question: Zonular cataract is seen in?
exp: ANSWER: (B) Hypoparathyroidism. REF: Parson's 20th ed p. 255-257. Morphological classification of developmental cataracts: Punctuate or blue dot. Most common congenital cataract almost universally seen in minute amounts. Types: Blue dot or cataracta coerulea: seen as blue dots with slit lamp Sutural or anterior axial: crowded in sutures Cataracta centralis pulverulenta: powdery white dots. Zonular/lamellar/perinudear cataract. Most common visually significant congenital cataract Sharp opacity around embryonic nucleus Spokes or riders may be seen. Assoc with maternal malnutrition, vit. D deficiency, hypoparathyroidism (hypocalcemia), during pregnancy. Fusiform/ spindle/axial/coraliform Nuclear cataract. Assoc, with rubella or german measles. Coronary/supranuclear cataract. Develops around puberty as a corona of club shaped opacity around lens. Anterior capsular polar cataract Postr. Capsular polar cataract
